isis.stitle: Spanish - Guía para Localización de Fallas del Sistema Eléctrico - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD MODEL 292, 392, 492 - DISASSEMBLE - COMPONENTS

step2.para: The pitman arm may be located on the output shaft by two socket head aining set screws, a self locking nut, or by a split nut and bolt arrangement ( Figure 9).

figure.caption: Figure 9. Locate Pitman Arm on Output Shaft

warning.para: Do not pound on the pitman arm or apply excessive heat as damages to the pitman arm or output shaft could cause a serious accident at a later date. Welding of the pitman arm and shaft must be avoided at all times.

step2.para: The pitman arm may also be drawn onto the tapered spline of the output shaft with a one-piece retainer, with or without tab washer ( Figure 10). The early 592 steering gears used a similar installation, however, it was of a two-piece design ( Figure 11 and Figure 12).

figure.caption: Figure 10. One-Piece Retainer
Figure 11. Two-Piece Retainer
Figure 12. Two-Piece Retainer

step2.para: To remove the retainer, a short piece of 5/8 or 3/4 inch hard steel hexagon stock is inserted into the retainer. If equipped with tab washer, bend the two restraining tabs out so the retainer can be removed ( Figure 13, Figure 14 and Figure 15).

figure.caption: Figure 13. Removing Retainer
Figure 14. Removing Retainer
Figure 15. Removing Retainer

step2.para: The retainer is now screwed out of the output shaft. The two-piece retainer used on the 592 steering gear is removed with a standard socket arrangement.

step1.para: Separate the mounting bracket from the steering gear, if used ( Figure 16).

figure.caption: Figure 16. Separate Mounting Bracket From Steering Gear

step1.para: Make reference marks on the bearing cap, cylinder head and housing so that the steering gear can be reassembled in the same configuration ( Figure 17).

figure.caption: Figure 17. Make Reference Marks on Bearing Cap, Cylinder Head and Housing

note.para: The cylinder head and bearing cap will fit either end of the housing.

step1.para: Remove the relief valve plungers from the cylinder head and the bearing cap. This will protect them from damage during repairs ( Figure 18).

figure.caption: Figure 18. Remove Relief Valve Plungers From Cylinder Head and Bearing Cap

step1.para: Clean the exposed portion of the output shaft to prevent damaging the bearing ( Figure 19).

figure.caption: Figure 19. Clean Exposed Portion of Output Shaft

step1.para: Remove the eight bolts attaching the pinion gear cover to the housing ( Figure 20).

figure.caption: Figure 20. Remove Bolts Attaching Pinion Gear Cover to Housing

step1.para: Use a soft hammer to tap on the end of the output shaft to loosen the cover ( Figure 21).

figure.caption: Figure 21. Tap on End of Output Shaft to Loosen Cover

step1.para: Carefully slide the output shaft, pinion gear, and cover through the housing. Pull the output shaft out of the cover. Remove and discard the cover O-ring seal ( Figure 22).

figure.caption: Figure 22. Slide Output Shaft, Pinion Gear, and Cover Through Housing

note.para: Early Series 5 steering gears used loose needle roller bearings in the cover and housing to support the output shaft. On disassembly, the needle rollers for the two bearings must be kept separate ( Figure 23). Refer to SERIES 5 HOUSING REPAIR

figure.caption: Figure 23. Loose Needle Roller Bearings

step1.para: Remove the cylinder head and discard the seal ring ( Figure 24).

figure.caption: Figure 24. Remove Cylinder Head and Discard Seal Ring
Figure 25. Remove Bolts From Bearing Cap

step1.para: Support the bearing cap and turn the actuating shaft until it is free of the piston. Remove and discard the seal ring ( Figure 26).

figure.caption: Figure 26. Turn Actuating Shaft Until Free of Piston

step1.para: Carefully slide the piston assembly from the bore of the housing ( Figure 27).

figure.caption: Figure 27. Slide Piston Assembly From Bore of Housing

note.para: Series 6 gears are equipped with piston rings. Care must be taken not to damage piston rings when removing the piston from the housing.

step1.para: The steering gear has now been disassembled into subassemblies which can be further disassembled and repaired as required ( Figure 28).

figure.caption: Figure 28. Steering Gear Subassemblies
